content:
I want to write a dockerfile to build the datasets project.
Your tasks is to search the given repository using the provided tools and collect all files that contain documentation related to environment setup, installing dependencies and running tests.
You musnt try to install the repository using pip. `pip install datasets` is NOT what we want to find, this is INCORRECT and IRRELEVANT to building the project from source, which is our goal.
Such content could be found in files with names like "testing", "contributing", "setup", etc. Collecting an irrelevant file could harm future results, so make sure that any file you register is indeed relevant.
To reiterate, a file that makes explicit mention of **how to install the project's dependencies** or how to **run unit tests** is considered relevant. Anything else should be ignored.
Your focus should be on natural langauge documents. DO NOT attempt to read or register python files, for example.
Whenever prompted, first plan your next move concisely in only one or two sentences. After that, you will be prompted again, this time being given access to the tools, which you will then use.
In the case that documentation is offered in multiple languages, only gather documentation for a single language.

Here are the contents of the repository's root directory (`.`):
- (dir) .dvc
- (dir) .github
- (dir) benchmarks
- (dir) docs
- (dir) notebooks
- (dir) src
- (dir) templates
- (dir) tests
- (dir) utils
- (file) .dvcignore
- (file) .gitignore
- (file) .pre-commit-config.yaml
- (file) .zenodo.json
- (file) ADD_NEW_DATASET.md
- (file) AUTHORS
- (file) CITATION.cff
- (file) CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
- (file) CONTRIBUTING.md
- (file) LICENSE
- (file) Makefile
- (file) README.md
- (file) SECURITY.md
- (file) dvc.yaml
- (file) setup.py

I want to write a docker file to place inside this repo that will set up a development environment, install any dependencies and run tests to confirm it works.
Remember, instructions such as `pip install datasets` are NOT helpful. I want to build the project from source.
Using the gathered files, collect and summarise any information that may help me. The gatehred files, which you now have access to are:
- CONTRIBUTING.md
You may use the ['get_file_contents', 'inspect_header'] tools to reinspect the contents of these files if you wish, but you can not access any files other than these. Once you are done, use the submit_summary to give a summary of the information you found.

In one or two sentences, give your thoughts about the provided information, then describe what you would like to do next.
You can use provided tools to retrieve additional information about the repo's contents.
You may use the ['get_file_contents', 'inspect_header'] tools to reinspect the contents of these files if you wish, but you can not access any files other than these. Once you are done, use the submit_summary to give a summary of the information you found.

The information I currently have is limited to the "CONTRIBUTING.md" file, which may contain important details regarding environment setup, installing dependencies, and running tests. My next step is to retrieve the contents of the "CONTRIBUTING.md" file to extract relevant instructions for setting up the development environment and testing processes.
Now, use the tool that you planned to use.

name: get_file_contents
content:
here are the section headers of the file: 
 - 
 - How to contribute to Datasets?
 - How to work on an open Issue?
 - How to create a Pull Request?
 - How to add a dataset
 - How to contribute to the dataset cards
 You can use the `inspect_header` function to see the content any file heading.
use the tools to either get more information or conclude your task once you are confident.

In one or two sentences, give your thoughts about the provided information, then describe what you would like to do next.
You can use provided tools to retrieve additional information about the repo's contents.
You may use the ['get_file_contents', 'inspect_header'] tools to reinspect the contents of these files if you wish, but you can not access any files other than these. Once you are done, use the submit_summary to give a summary of the information you found.

The "CONTRIBUTING.md" file appears to have headers that focus on contributing processes but does not explicitly suggest environment setup or dependency installation, which are crucial for building the project from source. I will inspect each section of the "CONTRIBUTING.md" file to see if any content within these headers provides details relevant to setting up the project and running tests.
Now, use the tool that you planned to use.

name: inspect_header
content:
here are the contents of CONTRIBUTING.md'sHow to contribute to Datasets? section:
"
[![Contributor Covenant](https://img.shields.io/badge/Contributor%20Covenant-2.0-4baaaa.svg)](CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

Datasets is an open source project, so all contributions and suggestions are welcome.

You can contribute in many different ways: giving ideas, answering questions, reporting bugs, proposing enhancements,
improving the documentation, fixing bugs,...

Many thanks in advance to every contributor.

In order to facilitate healthy, constructive behavior in an open and inclusive community, we all respect and abide by
our [code of conduct](CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).

"
use the tools to either get more information or conclude your task once you are confident.

In one or two sentences, give your thoughts about the provided information, then describe what you would like to do next.

The "How to contribute to Datasets?" section acknowledges the open-source nature of the project and encourages contributions, but it does not provide any practical information on setting up the development environment or installing dependencies. I will now proceed to inspect the next section titled "How to work on an open Issue?" to see if it contains relevant setup or testing instructions.
Now, use the tool that you planned to use.

name: inspect_header
content:
here are the contents of CONTRIBUTING.md'sHow to work on an open Issue? section:
"
You have the list of open Issues at: https://github.com/huggingface/datasets/issues

Some of them may have the label `help wanted`: that means that any contributor is welcomed!

If you would like to work on any of the open Issues:

1. Make sure it is not already assigned to someone else. You have the assignee (if any) on the top of the right column of the Issue page.

2. You can self-assign it by commenting on the Issue page with the keyword: `#self-assign`.

3. Work on your self-assigned issue and eventually create a Pull Request.

"
use the tools to either get more information or conclude your task once you are confident.

name: inspect_header
content:
here are the contents of CONTRIBUTING.md'sHow to create a Pull Request? section:
"
If you want to add a dataset see specific instructions in the section [*How to add a dataset*](#how-to-add-a-dataset).

1. Fork the [repository](https://github.com/huggingface/datasets) by clicking on the 'Fork' button on the repository's page. This creates a copy of the code under your GitHub user account.

2. Clone your fork to your local disk, and add the base repository as a remote:

    ```bash
    git clone git@github.com:<your Github handle>/datasets.git
    cd datasets
    git remote add upstream https://github.com/huggingface/datasets.git
    ```

3. Create a new branch to hold your development changes:

    ```bash
    git checkout -b a-descriptive-name-for-my-changes
    ```

    **do not** work on the `main` branch.

4. Set up a development environment by running the following command in a virtual environment:

    ```bash
    pip install -e ".[dev]"
    ```

   (If datasets was already installed in the virtual environment, remove
   it with `pip uninstall datasets` before reinstalling it in editable
   mode with the `-e` flag.)

5. Develop the features on your branch.

6. Format your code. Run `black` and `ruff` so that your newly added files look nice with the following command:

    ```bash
    make style
    ```
   
7. _(Optional)_ You can also use [`pre-commit`](https://pre-commit.com/) to format your code automatically each time run `git commit`, instead of running `make style` manually. 
To do this, install `pre-commit` via `pip install pre-commit` and then run `pre-commit install` in the project's root directory to set up the hooks.
Note that if any files were formatted by `pre-commit` hooks during committing, you have to run `git commit` again .


8. Once you're happy with your contribution, add your changed files and make a commit to record your changes locally:

    ```bash
    git add -u
    git commit
    ```

    It is a good idea to sync your copy of the code with the original
    repository regularly. This way you can quickly account for changes:

    ```bash
    git fetch upstream
    git rebase upstream/main
    ```

9. Once you are satisfied, push the changes to your fork repo using:

   ```bash
   git push -u origin a-descriptive-name-for-my-changes
   ```

   Go the webpage of your fork on GitHub. Click on "Pull request" to send your to the project maintainers for review.

"
use the tools to either get more information or conclude your task once you are confident.

In one or two sentences, give your thoughts about the provided information, then describe what you would like to do next.
You can use provided tools to retrieve additional information about the repo's contents.
You may use the ['get_file_contents', 'inspect_header'] tools to reinspect the contents of these files if you wish, but you can not access any files other than these. Once you are done, use the submit_summary to give a summary of the information you found.

The "How to create a Pull Request?" section provides essential instructions for setting up a development environment, specifically noting the use of `pip install -e ".[dev]"` to install dependencies in editable mode, which is critical for building the project from source. I will now proceed to inspect the next section titled "How to add a dataset?" to see if it includes any additional relevant information on running tests or environment setup.
Now, use the tool that you planned to use.

here are the contents of CONTRIBUTING.md'sHow to add a dataset section:
"

You can share your dataset on https://huggingface.co/datasets directly using your account, see the documentation:

* [Create a dataset and upload files on the website](https://huggingface.co/docs/datasets/upload_dataset)
* [Advanced guide using the CLI](https://huggingface.co/docs/datasets/share)

"
use the tools to either get more information or conclude your task once you are confident.

You may use the ['get_file_contents', 'inspect_header'] tools to reinspect the contents of these files if you wish, but you can not access any files other than these. Once you are done, use the submit_summary to give a summary of the information you found.

The "How to add a dataset?" section discusses sharing datasets on the Hugging Face platform and provides links to documentation for further guidance, but it does not address environment setup, installing dependencies, or running tests. Since I have explored all relevant sections of the "CONTRIBUTING.md" file, I will now submit a summary of the pertinent information I've gathered regarding setting up the development environment for the project.
Now, use the tool that you planned to use.

function.name: submit_summary
function.arguments: {"summary":"The 'CONTRIBUTING.md' file provides essential information for setting up the development environment for the datasets project. Specifically, it advises to set up the environment by running 'pip install -e .[dev]' in a virtual environment to install dependencies in editable mode. However, the file does not explicitly cover running tests or other detailed instructions related to testing."}

name: submit_summary
content: ok.

Now that you have gathered sufficient information about the repository, your new task is write a dockerfile that will be placed inside (https://github.com/huggingface/datasets.git) and will setup a working environment for the repository. To verify that any cloning and installation succeeds, `RUN` the repo's test suite at the end of the build process.
Here are some tips for successfully writing a dockerfile:
- Since the dockerfile will be placed inside the repository, there is no need to clone the repo!
- To ensure that you dont miss any files important to installing the requirements, make sure to copy the *entirety* of the repo into the container. (`COPY . /app/`)
- make sure that the tests run during the build process, by using `RUN` when running tests. If the final line uses `CMD` then I will be eaten alive (bad). DO NOT EVER USE `CMD <test command>`.
    - Dont add any additional arguments to the test command, that makes it harder for me to identify whether the build was successful.
    - Make sure your final line is `RUN <test command>`

use the `submit_dockerfile` function to provide the dockerfile.

function.name: submit_dockerfile
function.description: Given your current knowledge of the repo, provide a dockerfile to this function that clones the repo and sets up the repo, then runs tests

function.name: submit_dockerfile
function.arguments:
{"dockerfile":"# Use the official Python image as a parent image
FROM python:3.9-slim

# Set the working directory in the container
WORKDIR /app

# Copy the entire repository into the container
COPY . /app/

# Install the required packages in editable mode
RUN pip install -e .[dev]

# Run the test suite to verify installation
RUN pytest"}

name: submit_dockerfile
content: ok.
